title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with HF, vital signs and evidence of clinical congestion should be assessed at each encounter to guide overall management, including adjustment of diuretics and other medications.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with symptomatic HF, clinical factors indicating the presence of advanced HF should be sought via the history and physical examination.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with cardiomyopathy, a 3-generation family history should be obtained or updated when assessing the cause of the cardiomyopathy to identify possible inherited disease.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should direct diagnostic strategies to uncover specific causes that may warrant disease-specific management.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should be obtained and performed to identify cardiac and noncardiac disorders, lifestyle and behavioral factors, and social determinants of health that might cause or accelerate the development or progression of HF.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. For patients presenting with HF, the specific cause of HF should be explored using additional laboratory testing for appropriate management (1-8).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. For patients who are diagnosed with HF, laboratory evaluation should include complete blood count, urinalysis, serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, glucose, lipid profile, liver function tests, iron studies, and thyroid-stimulating hormone to optimize management.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. For all patients presenting with HF, a 12-lead ECG should be performed at the initial encounter to optimize management.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients presenting with dyspnea, measurement of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is useful to support a diagnosis or exclusion of HF (1-12).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with chronic HF, measurements of BNP or NT-proBNP levels are recommended for risk stratification (11,13-29).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients hospitalized for HF, measurement of BNP or NT-proBNP levels at admission is recommended to establish prognosis (11,13-19).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients at risk of developing HF, BNP or NT-proBNP–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist, can be useful to prevent the development of LV dysfunction or new-onset HF (30,31).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients hospitalized for HF, a predischarge BNP or NT-proBNP level can be useful to inform the trajectory of the patient and establish a postdischarge prognosis (14,17,20-29).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In first-degree relatives of selected patients with genetic or inherited cardiomyopathies, genetic screening and counseling are recommended to detect cardiac disease and prompt consideration of treatments to decrease HF progression and sudden death (1,2).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In select patients with nonischemic cardiomyopathy, referral for genetic counseling and testing is reasonable to identify conditions that could guide treatment for patients and family members (3,4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: **Ask Specifically About Family Members With**

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Any mention of cardiomyopathy, enlarged or weak heart, HF. Document even if attributed to other causes, such as alcohol or peripartum cardiomyopathy.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
rating: Right ventricular thinning or fatty replacement on imaging or biopsy

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Long QT or Brugada syndrome
rating: Abnormal high or low voltage or conduction, and repolarization, altered RV forces

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: ICD
rating: Frequent NSVT or very frequent PVCs

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Recurrent syncope

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Sudden death attributed to “massive heart attack” without known CAD

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Unexplained fatal event such as drowning or single-vehicle crash

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: “Lone” AF before age 65 y

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Pacemaker before age 65 y

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Any known skeletal muscle disease, including mention of Duchenne and Becker’s, Emory-Dreifuss limb-girdle dystrophy

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Systemic syndromes:

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Dysmorphic features
rating: Other possible manifestations of systemic syndromes

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Mental retardation

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Neurofibromatosis

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Renal failure with neuropathy

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: **RECOMMENDATIONS**

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with suspected or new-onset HF, or those presenting with acute decompensated HF, a chest x-ray should be performed to assess heart size and pulmonary congestion and to detect alternative cardiac, pulmonary, and other diseases that may cause or contribute to the patient’s symptoms (1,2).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with suspected or newly diagnosed HF, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) should be performed during initial evaluation to assess cardiac structure and function (3).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with HF who have had a significant clinical change, or who have received GDMT and are being considered for invasive procedures or device therapy, repeat measurement of EF, degree of structural remodeling, and valvular function are useful to inform therapeutic interventions (4-7).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients for whom echocardiography is inadequate, alternative imaging (e.g., cardiac magnetic resonance [CMR], cardiac computed tomography [CT], radionuclide imaging) is recommended for assessment of LVEF (8-15).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients with HF or cardiomyopathy, CMR can be useful for diagnosis or management (16-23).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 6. In patients with HF, an evaluation for possible ischemic heart disease can be useful to identify the cause and guide management (24-27).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with HF, endomyocardial biopsy may be useful when a specific diagnosis is suspected that would influence therapy (1,2).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In selected patients with HF with persistent or worsening symptoms, signs, diagnostic parameters, and in whom hemodynamics are uncertain, invasive hemodynamic monitoring can be useful to guide management.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with HF, routine use of invasive hemodynamic monitoring is not recommended (3,4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. For patients undergoing routine evaluation of HF, endomyocardial biopsy should not be performed because of the risk of complications (5,6).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Value Statement: Uncertain Value (B-NR)

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In selected adult patients with NYHA class III HF and history of a HF hospitalization in the past year or elevated natriuretic peptide levels, on maximally tolerated stable doses of GDMT with optimal device therapy, the usefulness of wireless monitoring of PA pressure by an implanted hemodynamic monitor to reduce the risk of subsequent HF hospitalizations is uncertain (1-4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with NYHA class III HF with a HF hospitalization within the previous year, wireless monitoring of the PA pressure by an implanted hemodynamic monitor provides uncertain value (4-7).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HF, assessment and documentation of NYHA functional classification are recommended to determine eligibility for treatments (1-3).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In selected ambulatory patients with HF, cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is recommended to determine appropriateness of advanced treatments (e.g., LVAD, heart transplant) (4-8).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In ambulatory patients with HF, performing a CPET or 6-minute walk test is reasonable to assess functional capacity (4,5,9-16).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In ambulatory patients with unexplained dyspnea, CPET is reasonable to evaluate the cause of dyspnea (17,18).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In ambulatory or hospitalized patients with HF, validated multivariable risk scores can be useful to estimate subsequent risk of mortality (1-14).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Year Published

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_class: ADHERE Classification and Regression Tree (CART) Model

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_class: AHA Get With The Guidelines Score

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_class: ESCAPE Risk Model and Discharge Score

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension to prevent symptomatic HF (1-9).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should be used to prevent hospitalizations for HF (10-12).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In the general population, healthy lifestyle habits such as regular physical activity, maintaining normal weight, healthy dietary patterns, and avoiding smoking are helpful to reduce future risk of HF (13-21).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. For patients at risk of developing HF, natriuretic peptide biomarker–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist optimizing GDMT, can be useful to prevent the development of LV dysfunction (systolic or diastolic) or new-onset HF (22,23).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In the general population, validated multivariable risk scores can be useful to estimate subsequent risk of incident HF (24-26).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Year Published

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality (1-4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events (5-9).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with a recent MI and LVEF ≤40% who are intolerant to ACEi, ARB should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality (10).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and LVEF ≤40%, evidence-based beta blockers should be used to reduce mortality (11-13).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients who are at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT and have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, an ICD is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death (SCD) to reduce total mortality (14).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 6. In patients with LVEF ≤40%, beta blockers should be used to prevent symptomatic HF (12,13).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 7. In patients with LVEF <50%, thiazolidinediones should not be used because they increase the risk of HF, including hospitalizations (15).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 8. In patients with LVEF <50%, nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers with negative inotropic effects may be harmful (16,17).

recommendation_class: Limited English proficiency or other language barriers (63)
rating: Routinely inquire in which language the patient is most comfortable conversing

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Determine eligibility for insurance or state-based transportation, or reduced-cost public transportation

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Maximize opportunities for telehealth visits and remote monitoring

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: For patients with stage C HF, avoiding excessive sodium intake is reasonable to reduce congestive symptoms (1-6).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: For patients with HF who are able to participate, exercise training (or regular physical activity) is recommended to improve functional status, exercise performance, and quality of life (QOL).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HF, a cardiac rehabilitation program can be useful to improve functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and health-related QOL.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HF who have fluid retention, diuretics are recommended to relieve congestion, improve symptoms, and prevent worsening HF.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: For patients with HF and congestive symptoms, addition of a thiazide (e.g., metolazone) to treatment with a loop diuretic should be reserved for patients who do not respond to moderate- or high-dose loop diuretics to minimize electrolyte abnormalities.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to III symptoms, the use of ARNi is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF, the use of ACEi is beneficial to reduce morbidity and mortality when the use of ARNi is not feasible.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF who are intolerant to ACEi because of cough or angioedema and when the use of ARNi is not feasible, the use of ARB is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: Value Statement: High Value (A)

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF, in whom ARNi is not feasible, treatment with an ACEi or ARB provides high economic value.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality (1-5).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 6. In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF, treatment with an ARNi instead of an ACEi provides high economic value (26-29).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 7. ARNi should not be administered concomitantly with ACEi or within 36 hours of the last dose of an ACEi (30,31).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 8. ARNi should not be administered to patients with any history of angioedema (32-35).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HFrEF, with current or previous symptoms, use of 1 of the 3 beta blockers proven to reduce mortality (e.g., bisoprolol, carvedilol, sustained-release metoprolol succinate) is recommended to reduce mortality and hospitalizations.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to IV symptoms, an MRA (spironolactone or eplerenone) is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality, if eGFR is >30 mL/min/1.73 m² and serum potassium is <5.0 mEq/L. Careful monitoring of potassium, renal function, and diuretic dosing should be performed at initiation and closely monitored thereafter to minimize risk of hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency (1-3).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients taking MRA whose serum potassium cannot be maintained at <5.5 mEq/L, MRA should be discontinued to avoid life-threatening hyperkalemia (8,9).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF, SGLT2i are recommended to reduce hospitalization for HF and cardiovascular mortality, irrespective of the presence of type 2 diabetes (1,2).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF, SGLT2i therapy provides intermediate economic value (3,4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: For patients self-identified as African American with NYHA class III-IV HFrEF who are receiving optimal medical therapy, the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is recommended to improve symptoms and reduce morbidity and mortality.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. For patients self-identified as African American with NYHA class III to IV HFrEF who are receiving optimal medical therapy with ACEi or ARB, beta blockers, and MRA, the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate provides high economic value.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with current or previous symptomatic HFrEF who cannot be given first-line agents, such as ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, because of drug intolerance or renal insufficiency, a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate might be considered to reduce morbidity and mortality.

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HF class II to IV symptoms, omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) supplementation may be reasonable to use as adjunctive therapy to reduce mortality and cardiovascular hospitalizations (1-4).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HF who experience hyperkalemia (serum potassium level ≥5.5 mEq/L) while taking a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAASi), the effectiveness of potassium binders (patiromer, sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) to improve outcomes by facilitating continuation of RAASi therapy is uncertain (5,6).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with chronic HFrEF without a specific indication (e.g., venous thromboembolism [VTE], AF, a previous thromboembolic event, or a cardioembolic source), anticoagulation is not recommended (7-9).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 1. In patients with HFrEF, dihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are not recommended treatment for HF (1,2).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 2. In patients with HFrEF, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and hormonal therapy are not recommended other than to correct specific deficiencies (3-9).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 3. In patients with HFrEF, nondihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are not recommended (10-13).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 4. In patients with HFrEF, class IC antiarrhythmic medications and dronedarone may increase the risk of mortality (14-16).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 5. In patients with HFrEF, thiazolidinediones increase the risk of worsening HF symptoms and hospitalizations (17-21).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 6. In patients with type 2 diabetes and high cardiovascular risk, the dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors saxagliptin and alogliptin increase the risk of HF hospitalization and should be avoided in patients with HF (22-24).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: 7. In patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs worsen HF symptoms and should be avoided or withdrawn whenever possible (25-28).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HFrEF, titration of guideline-directed medication dosing to achieve target doses shown to be efficacious in RCTs is recommended, to reduce cardiovascular mortality and HF hospitalizations, unless not well tolerated (1-10).

title: Distal Radius Fracture Rehabilitation
recommendation_content: In patients with HFrEF, titration and optimization of guideline-directed medications as frequently as every 1 to 2 weeks depending on the patient’s symptoms, vital signs, and laboratory findings can be useful to optimize management.
